instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3126: What is 820-3126? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.820-4668: What is 820-4668? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello

This iMac is with white screen of death and I just bought a K2100 to solve this issue

However when dissambly I break 1 cap (<CAPACITOR>C3634</CAPACITOR>) and had to put back <RESISTOR>R3604</RESISTOR>. 

Not sure if I damage anyother thing. However I did a GOOD visual inspection and didn't find anything

Now it only has 1 LED light on the motherboard and half fan spin
Any idea where to look for the problem.

Can I use my lab PSU to inject voltage on the main rail? 12V?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C3634</CAPACITOR> isn't critical, can be left out.
Check diode mode between its pads.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
DIODE between <CAPACITOR>C3634</CAPACITOR> pads

black probe on PIN 2 GND
red probe PIN 1 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>

= 0.568v

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
For repair purpose, you can use 12 lab PSU.
Removing CMOS battery will force board turn on when power is applied.

Just in case, check if starts in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Removed the CMOS!

Still not turning on and HALF FAN SPIN
SMC BYPASS mode try to start but only gives HALF SPIN


INJECTING 12V @ <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL>

NO FAN SPIN AT ALL
REMOVED THE CMOS = WHICH I UNDERSTAND = AUTO TURN ON

Should I turn on the board with a tweezer?
If so please confirm wich is the right pad/component to touch with the tweezer?

Below are the measurements on the board after injecting 12V on <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> (C610)

LED 1 = WORKING
LED 2 = OFF
LED 3 = OFF
LED 4 = OFF

<SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> = 12V
<SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
PP3V42 = 3.40V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3.30V (Measured on R502 right besides LED 2 which still OFF)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.message:
The only thing which I do not think is important to inform you. However I am giving you the image was the J4521 connector which is connected to the DVD/ROM it broke when I was removing the cable. However do not think is bad or critical for the board to work normally

image attached

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
J4521 is not important, if doesn't cause any short.

As you get S3 voltages, board started power on sequence.
Don't need to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; S5010 pads can be used, if really need that.

Do you get <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>?

threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V

Sorry did not understand

After giving full power rails info. Where would you recommend me going to check?

threads.message: J4521 is not in short in any of its PADS.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
I also tried to power on the board with a TWEEZER on S5010 (PIN 1 AND PIN GROUND) and didn't happen anything.

Only still LED 1 ON

I am bit lost where to go on this one

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Mmmmh, this old machine has <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> FET placed into its PSU.
Injecting 12V from lab PSU directly doesn't help.
You can try to run a wire between <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>, for this purpose.
Be sure first no short there.

I recommend to use original known good PSU.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: Is there a test to check if original PSU is good? It came working normally. The problem was white screen of death VGA problem.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Be aware, working with high voltage device is dangerous!!!

According with schematic, iMac PSU can be tested forcing <SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL> signal; it should bring on <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> output.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Percect!

What means FORCING <SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL>? Can you give me more details?

<SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> is not shorted to ground. It DOES not beep to ground in continuity

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
I don't recommend to work with PSU alone.
If PSU is connected to MLB, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; <SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL> should change its status.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
I am not telling to work with the PSU alone. I am asking if is there a way to know if the iMac PSU is good or not.

HOWEVER

I just assembled again the machine and now I do not have LED 1 with the original PSU. 

Maybe its bad

I put it back ON with 12V on the PSU LAB and LED 1 (Just a reminder that now the board is without CMOS battery)

I gonna put my questions below

1) Is there a way to check if original iMac PSU is working good? If yes please detail how to

2) Injecting 12V on <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> makes LED 1 ON = Is this the expected behavior? Or should LED 2 TURN ON?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
The iMac original PSU does not make any sense to be BAD.

It came as white screen of death. Turning ON and OFF normally.

PAY ATTENTION to this

I assemble this board into another working machine with a known good PSU

It did same thing 

With pressing power HALF SPIN stop HALF SPIN again still ONLY LED 1 OK
With SMC BYPASS samething however HALF SPIN try to start stronger ONLY LED 1 OK

HOWEVER ALL OF SUDDEN

Twice it turn on the second LED. 

I turn off from the power cord assemble the screen and back to the same behavior


With pressing power HALF SPIN stop HALF SPIN again still ONLY LED 1 OK
With SMC BYPASS samething however HALF SPIN try to start stronger ONLY LED 1 OK


ANDDDD NOWWWW

Assembling it back to the original PSU it appears the LED 1 for a second and then turn off.

Now with its OWN psu I do not have LED anymore.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: Change <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and test again.

threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> with a <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4668</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which according to the schematic is the same IC.

Same behavior with PSU lab 

Only LED 1 active
0.050a on the PSU lab

Tried to trigger ON <CAPACITOR>C5014</CAPACITOR> with a twezzer and still only LED 1 active

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
As I said, <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> is provided from iMac PSU.
If you inject 12V with lab PSU just into <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> rail, board will never start!

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Just measured <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL>

Actually

Its around 0.500V and then it tries to go up sometimes it shows 8V / 9V and then back to 0.500v in loop.

That's the behavior.

Didnt even tried to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> after seeing it. I guess it needs to be stable in order to work.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> must be triggered for short time only, like pressing power button.
<SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL> should go low at same time.

When <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> tries to appear, check for pulse at big coils and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Be sure no short on any coil...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Yes when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I use a tweezer on both sides of the cap I mentioned above. Is it the correct way? If not please detail how to do it properly.

<SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL> =  3.96 for some seconds and then goes to 0 and then back to 3.96
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.030v and then goes to 0V and then tries to go back
<SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> =   Its around 0.500V and then it tries to go up sometimes it shows 8V / 9V and then back to 0.500v in loop.

L7100
PIN 1 =  Same behavior as <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>
PIN 2 = Same behavior as <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
In my opinion, is more convenient to solder a wire on corresponding pad os S5010 and touch any metal placa to simulate power button.
This way also helps you to test starting in SMC bypass mode.

I didn't see any mention about output voltages from pages 68, 69 & 71.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> more times; helps to catch higher pulses...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Thanks for the advice however still prefer to use a tweezer.

To measure the outpages on the pages you requested Its on the other side of the board I will probably need to measure it with PSU lab. Is that OK? Since you told me it doesn't put <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> to work?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
You can't test the board without <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.
You can try to make a bypass from <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.
This may not work, if PCH timing is not respected, for power on sequence.

Use a spare iMac PSU, to work on the desk.
You don't need to connect internal LCD, nor speakers.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>12V_S0_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> is not named this on the boardview file

<RESISTOR>R7082</RESISTOR> was not measuring 2K and only have voltage on pin1 and nothing on pin 2. Replaced with another one and now I do have 12V on both pin and looks like the board is trying to start sometimes. I will assemble to test.

But I still do not have LED 2 and the funny thing is I've got <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board to replace it and it was measuring 2K on the board.. After replacing it on the iMac board its not giving 2K ohms on the multimeter but I do have 12V on both pin.

REALLY WEIRD.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
An onboard measurment for resistor can give you different reading than nominal.
That's normal, more components connected there affect onboard value.

"<SIGNAL>12V_S0_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> is not named this on the boardview file"
I'm sure you can locate one component connected to it on schematic in boardview too.
Learn how to use schematic/boardview; such reply is not acceptable for a technician!

Did you test it now with its original iMac PSU?
Remember to remove the short between <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.

For sure I remove the jumper before doing anything else.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
NOW

Measuring with PSU LAB

page 68
<RESISTOR>R7467</RESISTOR> which is the VDD tries to go high and then back to 0V

Page 69
<CAPACITOR>C7516</CAPACITOR> = Stable 0.560V
<CAPACITOR>C7510</CAPACITOR> which is the output tries to go high and then back to 0V

Page 70
L7750 tries to go high and then back to 0V on both pins
L7710 stable 3.3V

Page 71
L7830 tries to go high and then back to 0V on both pins

Page 72
Mentioned on the start of the thread its 3.40v

Page 73
<CHIP>U8000</CHIP> PIN6 tries to go high and then back to 0V
<CHIP>U8053</CHIP> PIN6 tries to go high and then back to 0V
<CHIP>U8050</CHIP> PIN6 tries to go high and then back to 0V
<CHIP>U8025</CHIP> PIN6 tries to go high and then back to 0V

Page 74
<RESISTOR>R8132</RESISTOR> stable 11.93 on both pins

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>12V_S0_PWRCTL</SIGNAL>  is also stable using PSU LAB @ 11.95v

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
The problem with lab PSU is that PCH timings are not respected; <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> being present even in S5 state.
If you can confirm that a good working board boots in this way, then is safe to continue the repair process with lab PSU.
Until then, is better to remove original PSU and use it with the board on the desk.

Mentioned pages contain lot of secondary voltages.
You must be sure first there is no short; on any output rail.
Then check for voltage pulse.
Some of these secondary voltages have a power good signal, which is needed to get correct <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
For example, on page 68, <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is what you need to check (L7420).
On page 69 should check (pulse) voltage for D and S of <TRANSISTOR>Q7500</TRANSISTOR>.
You forget to check L7850 on page 71.

"Yes I tried SMC bypass and its same behavior I already told you"
Did you try it after changing <RESISTOR>R7082</RESISTOR>?

Check for pulse at pin 8 & 11 of <CHIP>U7050</CHIP>; also at L7201.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> is present.
Check if <SIGNAL>PS_ON</SIGNAL> stays low at same time.
<SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> FET is inside PSU.
If no short, or low resistance to ground, <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> MUST come on.
If not, try another PSU...

It can be repaired, but be aware of high voltage risk!

To SDD NO; you can use a SATA power cable from a desktop PC.
Apart of power overload, I don't see anything elese common between thunderbolt and SATA port.
Just told you how to discard anything else related with SATA; like disconnecting L4511 (did it?).

You can't discard original iMac PSU, so that is still a possible reason.
Maybe it can't support SATA, or/and thunderbolt consumption.

Still not sure about board behavior.
"I REMOVE the idea of SATA being bad since it does not have any issue with it only connected"
Do you mean board stays on (chime, USB activity) with HDD connetced now?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: Is there a test to make sure iMac PSU is good or not? I think it's supposed to be good since it turn on without these things connected to the board.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
There is a way, not sure if works.
Connecting together <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL> with <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> may not like to PCH; because of timing issues.
I think you tried this on the first posts, don't remember now.

Just try connecting 12V from lab PSU to pins 1-3 of J600 at same time; set amp limit to max.
Disconnect any cable from iMac PSU and MLB first.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
I already did that.

Look like you are also in a LOOP

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: If its PSU is good, I can only think about some damage caused to SMC, when ODD was connect in reverse way to J4521; via <SIGNAL>SMC_ODD_DETECT</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: Would you do what then? Replace SMC to test? By now do you think iMac PSU is 100% working? Is there any other test that I could make or the above makes it a working PSU?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
You can't discard PSU until try known good one.
But is more likely a problem caused by power ODD wrong connection.
Not sure if this could also affected PCH...

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message: What would you do to fix customer problem? Buy a new logic board? buy a new PSU? buy a new logic board + psu?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3126</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Half Fan Spin
threads.message:
Sometime the cost may not deserve the repair.
And I don't talk about components price only.
You should appreciate your time involved in the repair too.

Finding replacement MLB for iMac is not so easy.
Also not easy to find scrap one, to get the SMC.
